title: Feeding back
body:
With a bit of preparation, a visit to the GP should be a positive experience, helping you take a step towards feeling better.

Your first visit to the GP is the start of a new relationship. You and your GP need to work together to understand each other. But sometimes, relationships can be difficult for all kinds of reasons.

If you aren’t happy with how your first visit went, it’s best to raise this with you GP so they can change things for future visits. You could bring it up the next time you see them, or even send them a letter explaining what didn’t work for you.

Some reasons people give for feeling unhappy with GP visits include feeling like their GP is not listening to them, feeling that the GP didn’t know enough about mental health, feeling patronised, being dismissed or not being taken seriously, or feeling like the GP didn’t explain things well or used too much confusing language.

You can always request to see a different GP the next time you make an appointment. You can even ask if anyone working at the practice specialises in mental health. Remember, you can ask to speak to a receptionist at a practice in private if you need to.If you wish to make a formal complaint about a GP or another member of staff in a practice, there are steps you can take.

All GP practices should have a written complaints procedure, which reception staff should give to you if you ask for it. The complaints procedure might also be available on the practice website. You can also ask at reception for a meeting with the Practice Manager or write a letter to the Practice Manager listing the things you’re unhappy about.

If you don’t feel that your complaint is being dealt with, you could speak to your local Healthwatch or Health board. These local organisations are ‘consumer champions’ for people who use health and social care services. If your GP surgery is in England, you can find your local Healthwatch at Healthwatch.co.uk. Local Healthwatch organisations vary in what level of support and advice they give.

If your GP surgery is in Scotland, you can register a complaint on mygov.scot.

If your GP surgery is in Wales, you can register a complaint with Health in Wales.

If your GP surgery is in Northern Ireland, you can register a complaint with NI direct.

The body that regulates doctors is the General Medical Council. Here is their guide to what you should expect from a doctor: GMC Guidance

This is The General Medical Council’s guide to complaining about a doctor: GMC-Complaints

You can change GP practice at any time to another practice that is accepting new patients.

title: Your GP
body:
A general practitioner, or GP, is a local doctor who can help with all kinds of health related questions. They’re usually based at health centres in the community called practices. Most practices have more than one doctor.

GPs are not usually specialists in specific areas of medicine. Rather, they are available to help you look after your general health and wellbeing. A GP can give you advice, prescribe medicines and treatments and refer you to specialists for more specific care. It’s their job to help you get the care you need to be as healthy as you can be.

GPs are here to help you look out for your whole health, both physical and mental health. Feeling sad, confused, angry, anxious or having disruptive thoughts can affect your health just as much as physical injury.

When you see a GP, they’ll ask you questions about any health problem that is troubling you. After asking questions, having a discussion with you, and perhaps looking at any physically affected areas, they will then be able to explain what they think might be causing your health problems. They will suggest treatments and a course of action to help you get better.

You’ll find that you work best with your GP when you’ve begun to build a relationship together, so they understand you and you feel comfortable talking about your concerns. It’s better to go and see a GP before any problems get more serious.

title: What are my rights?
body:
When you are making your appointment:

  • When you make your first appointment at a GP you have a right to ask to see either a female doctor or a male doctor.

  • If you already have a GP whom you like and trust, you can always request to see him or her when you make an appointment.

    • You should also be able to book appointments in advance. This might help you to see a doctor that you like and trust.

    You have a right to book a double appointment (20 minutes rather than the usual 10) if you feel like you need it.

    You also have the right to speak to the receptionist at the GP practice in private if you need to. You don’t have to tell the receptionist details about why you are booking an appointment, but it might help them to make sure you get an appointment with the right person.

    Once you have made your appointment:

  • Your doctor cannot tell your family anything about your health without your permission.

    • If you’re over 16 you can provide consent for you own treatment. This means that you can take the decisions over what treatments you do and don’t have. A doctor is not allowed to tell your parents, carers or family members unless you agree.

    If you are under 16 you can make the same decisions if you can fully understand what the options are and what a particular treatment involves. This means you can also refuse a treatment if it doesn’t feel right for you and ask about alternatives.

title: What should I expect?
body:
The usual length of a consultation with a GP is 10 minutes. In that time a GP will try to find out what is wrong, get an idea of your overall health and also try to work out what the next steps will be for your treatment.

Once you tell the GP what is on your mind they will probably ask you some questions. This is because they are trying to get a better idea of what is going on for you and what might help.

GPs can seem in a bit of a hurry sometimes. They often have to be very focused to fit in all of their patients in the day. If they ask you lots of questions this means they are trying to work out what might be wrong, don’t be put off.

Don’t be worried about being honest about what’s happening in your head and telling them how you’re feeling. They are there to help. While GPs aren’t usually specialists in mental health, they are used to listening to people’s problems.

The way to think about your first visit to the GP is that it’s the start of a journey to getting stuff sorted out, not the end destination.

Depending on what’s happening for you and at what point in your life you’re at, your GP might do a number of things. They may refer you to a specialist, which will probably take some time to arrange; they might prescribe you some form of treatment or they might give you some advice, guidance or other suggestions for help. They will also probably suggest that you come back to see them again to see how you are getting on.

They will probably take some notes or enter some details into their computer system while you are with them.

title: Finding a GP
body:
Finding a GP differs depending on where you live:

  • If you live in England, visit NHS.uk site to find a GP near you.
  • If you live in Northern Ireland, visit Health and Social care online, to find a GP near you.
  • If you live in Scotland, visit the NHS inform site to find a GP near you.
  • If you live in Wales, visit NHS direct Wales to find a GP near you.

    • Remember, you can choose to change GPs if you wish to, even if your parents or other carer have previously registered you with a GP.

    GP practices are also listed in local telephone directories.

title: How do I make GP my appointment work for me?
body:
Getting prepared for your appointment is a good idea. Use our checklist to work out the things you want to talk to your GP about. GPs use what you tell them as a way to work out what might best help. If you don’t tell them enough, they won’t have enough information to suggest anything useful.

If it’s your first time talking to your GP about your mental health or problems that you’re having, you might want to book a double appointment. You do not have to tell any reception staff why you want a double appointment.

Right at the start of your appointment try to tell the GP what you want to talk about. When the GP asks you questions be as honest as you can. They’ll use what you say to work out what’s wrong or what might help, so it really helps to be open.

Your appointment should be a two-way conversation. It’s your appointment and your health so don’t be afraid to ask questions, especially if the doctor says something you don’t understand or which doesn’t sound right to you.

If you are really worried about the appointment you can take a friend or family member with you. This might give you more confidence to talk to the doctor. They could even tell the doctor about the problems or challenges that you’re having if you don’t feel confident enough.

Write down things that you have to remember about what was said. Ask the doctor if they have more information you can take away with you.

A good way to make sure you’ve understood what the GP has said to you is repeating it back to them, asking if you’ve got it right.

title: What is confidentiality about?
body:
Everything said in a consultation between you and a GP is confidential. This means they are not allowed to tell other people that you have been to see them. The same goes for reception staff.

Your GP might suggest you talk to other people about your problem, or ask for your permission to contact them on your behalf in situations where they feel it will help you. You do not have to say yes to this and they can’t contact anyone without your permission.

The doctor will usually write or type some notes about what was said, so that she or he has a record of them, but you can even ask them not to do that.

In the vast majority of situations, though, the GP can only contact others about your health with your permission.

The only time that confidentiality might be broken is if the GP feels you or someone else might be at risk of harm.

title: Doc Ready and your privacy
body:
Doc Ready doesn't store anything that we or anyone else can link to you. Nothing stays on the server and nothing stays on your phone or computer.

We do use Google Analytics to help us measure how we're doing and improve the site, but that data isn't linked to you in any way.

You can choose to email your checklist to yourself, or to download it, or to print it, and what you do with it then is up to you. We don't even store items people add to their checklists, just the topics people look at.

If you have any other questions or concerns about your privacy when using Doc Ready, please contact us.
